questions.question: A young man is brought to the emergency department following a road traffic accident. He was driving the car when the accident occurred. On examination, it is noted that the injured leg is shortened. The image of the pelvis radiograph is shown below. Which of the following nerves is most commonly injured in the given condition?
For which type of fractures does the Hawkins classification apply?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Talus Explanation: Hawkin’s classification is used for fractures of the neck of the talus . Hawkin’s classification: Type I Undisplaced fracture of the talar neck. Type II Displaced fracture with subluxation or dislocation of the subtalar joint. Type III Displaced fracture with dislocation of the talus body from the ankle joint. Type IV Displaced vertical talar neck fracture with associated disruption of the talonavicular joint. Tibia (Option B): The Schatzker classification is used for categorizing tibial fracture Humerus (Option C): The Neer's Classification is used for categorizing humerus head fracture. Calcaneus (Option D): The Sanders classification is primarily used for categorizing fractures of the calcaneus. Reference: Apley and Solomon’s System of Orthopaedics and Trauma, 10th Edition, Pages 766,925,951,955.

questions.question: The radiograph below depicts a patient who is experiencing persistent knee pain without any previous injury. Identify the specific condition displayed in the image?

options.B: Bipartite patella, X-ray of the opposite knee
options.C: Fracture of the upper pole of the patella, Cylindrical cast

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Bipartite fracture patella, X-ray of the opposite knee Explanation: In the absence of trauma with the given x-ray appearance showing 2 divided patellar segments is suggestive of Bipartite patella and the most appropriate next step in management is to take X-ray of opposite knee . Bipartite Patella: Definition A congenital condition where the patella (kneecap) is divided into two separate bone segments. Etiology Failure of ossification centers to fuse during development, resulting in separate bone fragments. Occurs in approximately 1-2% of the population, often bilateral. Anatomy Typically involves the superolateral corner of the patella. Types Based on the location of the secondary ossification centre, Type I: Inferior pole of patella. Type II: Lateral margin. Type III: Superolateral (most common). Symptoms Usually asymptomatic, but can cause anterior knee pain, especially after trauma or repetitive stress. Diagnosis X-ray: Shows the patella with a well-corticated fragment. MRI: Useful for assessing associated soft tissue injury or bone edema if symptomatic. Differential Diagnosis Patellar fracture (differs by smooth, rounded edges in bipartite patella vs sharp edges in fractures). Management Asymptomatic: No treatment required. Symptomatic: Rest, NSAIDs, physical therapy, or in severe cases, surgery (excision of fragment).

questions.question: What is the probable diagnosis for a child brought to the orthopedics OPD with a lower limb deformity and hyperpigmented skin lesions, based on the presented X-ray of her thigh?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Fibrous dysplasia Explanation: Lower limb deformity with x-ray showing ground glass lesion, ‘shepherd crook deformity’ with associated skin lesions is suggestive of Fibrous dysplasia . Fibrous dysplasia: Description Non-inherited developmental disorder causing replacement of bone by fibrous tissue Etiology GNAS1 gene mutation (Chromosome 20) Associated with McCune Albright syndrome - Polyostotic Fibrous Dysplasia Clinical presentation Usually presents in the 2nd decade Progressive limb pain, swelling Limb deformities with associated fractures Skin lesions (seen with McCune Albright syndrome) Radiography X-ray: well defined expansile intramedullary lesions with ‘ Ground glass ’ appearance, ‘shepherd crook deformity’ . MRI: is done to know the full extent of the disease Management Medical: Bisphosphonates Surgical: Deformity correction surgeries

questions.question: What could be the likely diagnosis based on the x-ray image of a 22-year-old female?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Giant cell tumor Explanation: Clinical scenario and x-ray showing eccentric expansile lytic lesion on epi-metaphyseal region is suggestive of Giant cell tumor/Osteoclastoma (GCT) . Osteoclastoma/ Giant Cell Tumor: Description Benign but locally aggressive tumor of bone. It commonly arises from epiphysis. MC Age: 20 and 45 years of age. Females > males. Sites affected Distal femur > proximal tibia > distal radius > sacrum. Malignancy Malignant transformation in <1% of cases. Lungs are the most common site for metastases. Clinical features Swelling, vague pain. Pathological fracture. Radiology X-ray: Expansile eccentric lytic lesion on epiphysis Management Extended curettage with Bone grafting Incorrect options: Chondroblastoma (Option A): Seen in 1st decade (before skeletal maturity) X-ray: Expansile eccentric epiphyseal lesion Biopsy: Chicken wire calcification is pathognomic Osteochondroma (Option B): The most common bone tumor (not a True bone tumor), usually presents as a painless lump. Radiography shows sessile pedunculated cartilage tumor

questions.question: A 30-year-old patient has limited hip movement and complains of pain and discomfort in the hip region. Which of the following tests is done to identify flexion deformity at the hip?
questions.explanation: contracture and to measure hip extension. If the patient has a hip flexion contracture, the contralateral knee will rise off the examination table when the hip on the affected side is extended. Thomas Test : Thomas Test is a clinical examination used to assess hip flexion contracture (tightness of the hip flexors), particularly the iliopsoas muscle. It helps detect hip flexor tightness or shortening which may be contributing to lower back or hip pain. The test is especially useful in diagnosing conditions such as iliopsoas syndrome or hip joint stiffness. Steps in Thomas Test: Position the Patient: Flex the Contralateral Hip: Assess the Involved Hip: While the opposite leg is held in flexion, observe the position of the involved leg (the leg lying flat on the table). Evaluate Knee Flexion Positive Thomas Test: The involved leg rises off the table or the knee remains flexed. This suggests hip flexor contracture (tightness of the iliopsoas or other hip flexors), which may limit the ability of the patient to fully extend the hip. Negative Thomas Test: The involved leg remains flat on the table, with little to no knee flexion, indicating that there is no significant hip flexor tightness. Telescopy (Option C) Identifies hip instability by moving the patient's leg in circular motion, observing abnormal hip joint movement, confirmed by visible and palpable greater trochanter displacement. Lasegue test (Option B) Identifies lumbar radiculopathy or sciatica by lifting the patient's straight leg while lying flat, pain indicating nerve root compression. McMurray test (Option D) Assesses knee meniscal tears by bending, twisting, and extending the patient's knee, pain or "click" suggests tear. Reference: Apley and Solomon’s System of Orthopedics and Trauma, 10th edition, Page 8

questions.question: A 80-year-old woman slipped and fell in the bathroom, experiencing pain and an inability to walk due to a left hip injury, without any prior osteoarthritis history, and with an observation of a shortened and externally rotated left lower limb according to X-ray findings, how would you plan to manage her condition?
questions.explanation: fracture. This patient is an elderly female who fell and is unable to walk, with shortened, externally rotated lower limb which is suggestive of displaced fracture of the neck of the femur. A hemiarthroplasty is the most appropriate option for this patient. It involves replacing the femoral head and neck with a prosthetic implant. This procedure is generally preferred for older patients with displaced femoral neck fractures, which the X-ray image indicates. Internal Fixation with Cancellous Screws (Option A) This option may be suitable for certain types of hip fractures, but it may not be appropriate for displaced femoral neck fractures, which are more common in the elderly. Meyer's

questions.question: A young male who met with a road traffic accident is brought to the emergency department. His left leg is shortened, internally rotated, and adducted. On examination, femoral artery pulsation is not felt. A plain radiograph of his lower limb was taken which is shown below. What is your diagnosis?

options.B: Fracture neck of femur with injury to femoral vessels
options.C: Anterior dislocation of hip with femoral artery injury

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) Posterior dislocation of hip Explanation: The scenario here points to the diagnosis of posterior dislocation of the hip , which presents the affected limb as internally rotated, adducted, flexed, and shortened (FADIR) . Sciatic nerve is commonly injured in posterior hip dislocation. Classification of the dislocations of the hip: Posterior dislocation: the most common type, often associated with acetabular lip fracture. Anterior dislocation: rare, typically due to forced abduction and external rotation. Central fracture-dislocation: the femoral head is driven through the acetabulum into the pelvic cavity. Posterior dislocation of hip Anterior dislocation of hip Central dislocation of hip Mechanism of injury: Caused by force along the

questions.question: A 74-year-old man, who was previously a weightlifter, presented with lower back pain that was radiating to his legs. On examination , a palpable step was felt in the lumbosacral region of the spine. The x-ray of the spine is given below. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Spondylolisthesis Explanation: Palpable step in the lumbosacral region with x-ray showing forward displacement of vertebra and intervertebral disc narrowing is suggestive of Spondylolisthesis . Spondylolisthesis It refers to the forward displacement of a vertebra over the one beneath it Commonly occurring at the L5-S1 and L4-L5 levels. Spondylolysis refers to a defect in the pars without the vertebra slipping forward . Classification Dysplastic Least common type Caused by congenital anomalies in the upper sacrum or L5 arch, facilitating the slip. Isthmic The most common type Involving a lesion in the pars interarticularis, which can be further divided into three subtypes: Lytic : A fatigue fracture of the pars interarticularis. Intact but elongated : The pars interarticularis remains intact but is elongated. Acute fracture : A recent fracture of the pars interarticularis. The defect causes the anterior half of the vertebra to slip forward while the posterior half remains with the lower vertebra. Degenerative Results from long-term intersegmental instability , where the pars remains intact, but degenerative changes in the facet joints permit forward slipping. Common in older adults, where instability in the posterior facet joints due to osteoarthritis can lead to displacement, occasionally backwards (retrolisthesis). Severe displacement and neurological issues are rare. Traumatic This results from fractures in other parts of the bony structure rather than in the pars interarticularis. Pathological Caused by generalized or localized bone diseases that weaken the vertebral articulations. X-ray Examination for

questions.question: What is the term used to describe the fracture shown in the image, which occurred due to a fall from a significant height?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Open book fracture Explanation: Both arches being separated at anterior and posterior ends caused by an anteroposterior compression injury to the pelvis is suggestive of Open Book fracture Pelvis . Open book - Pelvic ring fracture is classified under Class B1 of Tile’s classification of Pelvic ring injuries. Tile’s classification of Pelvic ring injuries: Type A: Stable (Intact posterior arch) A1 Avulsion injury A2 Iliac-wing or anterior arch fracture A3 Transverse sacrococcygeal fracture Type B: Partially stable (incomplete disruption of the posterior arch) B1 Open-book injury (external rotation) (Option A) B2 Lateral-compression injury (internal rotation) B2-1: Ipsilateral anterior and posterior injuries B2-2: Contralateral (bucket-handle) injuries (Option D) B3 Bilateral Type C: Unstable (complete disruption of the posterior arch) C1 Unilateral C2 Bilateral, with one side type B, one side type C C3 Bilateral Incorrect Options: Chauffeur Fracture (Option B): Type of intra-articular fracture of the radial styloid with radiostyloid joint subluxation . It is also known as Hutchinson or Backfire fracture. Malgaigne Fracture (Option C) : It is an unstable pelvic fracture characterized by anterior portion of pelvis namely pubic rami and posterior portion of the pelvis involving sacroiliac complex.

questions.question: A 45-year old female met with an accident and was brought to trauma centre and X-ray pelvis was performed and image is given below shows Intracapsular fracture NOF. What is the management in this case?
questions.explanation: Correct answer: D) Open reduction+ Internal fixation Explanation: The best course of management in an Intracapsular neck of femur fracture in a 45 year old female is open reduction and internal fixation, due to higher risk of avascular necrosis. Neck of femur fractures and intertrochanteric fractures Aspect Neck of Femur Fracture Intertrochanteric Fracture Location Intracapsular (within the joint capsule) Extracapsular (outside the joint capsule) Age Group Typically after 50 years Typically after 60 years Sex Female > Male Male > Female Common Patient Demographics Elderly (low-energy trauma like falls) Elderly (low-energy trauma); rare high-energy trauma in younger patients Mechanism of Injury Trivial, low-energy trauma (osteoporotic) Low-energy trauma in elderly; usually requires significant trauma in younger patients Stability Less stable, especially if displaced Generally unstable due to muscle forces and location Ability to Walk May be possible in impacted fractures Walking is not possible due to the instability External Rotation Deformity Less than 45º More than 45º Shortening Less than 1 inch More than 1 inch Blood Supply Involvement High risk of avascular necrosis (medial circumflex artery disruption) Lower risk of avascular necrosis Blood Loss Less blood loss due to intracapsular location More blood loss due to the involvement of surrounding vascular structures Pain, Severity, and Tenderness Mild to moderate pain localized to the groin/hip region. Tenderness is typically felt in Scarpa’s triangle. Severe pain, more generalized around the hip with marked tenderness over the greater trochanter. Weight-bearing is difficult or impossible. Treatment Options Non-displaced: Internal fixation (Option D) (e.g., cannulated screws) Displaced: Surgical fixation (hemiarthroplasty (Option B ruled out) , total hip replacement) Almost always requires internal fixation (e.g., dynamic hip screws, intramedullary nails) Complications High risk of nonunion and avascular necrosis Malunion is more common than nonunion Closed reduction (Option A) is not done because there is a high risk of avascular necrosis and non union of fracture Open + Closed reduction (Option C) cannot be done at the same time and is not the best course of action.

questions.question: Arrange the following in the correct sequence for the Thomas test: 1. Squaring of pelvis 2. Flexion of the hip 3. Look for exaggerated lumbar lordosis 4. Measure actual flexion deformity 5.Make sure that the ischial tuberosity makes contact with the ground. 6. Overcorrection of the normal side
questions.explanation: Assess the Involved Hip: While the opposite leg is held in flexion, observe the position of the involved leg (the leg lying flat on the table). Evaluate Knee Flexion Interpretation: If an opposite leg is flat: Good hip flexibility If the opposite leg lifts off the table, but the hip is flexed: Hip flexor contracture If the opposite leg lifts off and the hip is extended: The hip flexor and extensor contracture Hence the correct sequence of the Thomas test is: Look for exaggerated lumbar lordosis → Flexion of hip → Overcorrection of normal side → Ensure ischial tuberosity touches the ground → Measure actual flexion deformity. Squaring of the pelvis (Statement 1) is not done in Thomas’ test. Reference: Apley and Solomon’s System of Orthopedics and Trauma, 10th edition, Page 8

questions.question: A 45-year-old patient with a cast, due to tibia fracture, presented to the emergency department with complaints of intense pain. The cast was removed and on physical examination, passive extension of leg was painful. The dorsalis pedis and posterior tibial pulses were present and there was a loss of sensation over the first web space. What is the next step?
questions.explanation: syndrome. The next step is to measure the pressure in the anterior compartment if there is suspicion of compartment syndrome. Normal pressure at the leg is < 11 mm of Hg. Calf pressure during walking is 200-300 mm Hg. Pressure in compartment syndrome >40 mmHg. Acute compartment syndrome is caused by ischemia of a closed compartment of the body (most commonly forearm) which leads to increased intra-compartmental pressure. It may be due to a decrease in compartment size or an increase in the volume of the compartment. Prolonged ischemia will lead to myonecrosis stimulating fibrosis resulting in a fibrotic pull of the wrists and fingers. Causes include: Tight bandages and dressings Animal bites Burns Intensive and excessive exercises Muscle hypertrophy Neoplasms Bleeding into a closed compartment (injury to a vessel, congenital or acquired disorder) Injections in the forearm Surgery on the forearm Clinical Features: Initial Symptoms of Compartment Syndrome (Order of appearance) Pain : The earliest symptom , worsened by passive extension of fingers - Stretch pain Pallor : Skin may appear pale due to reduced blood supply. Pulselessness : Diminished or absent radial pulse. Paresthesia : Numbness or tingling due to nerve compression. Paralysis : Weakness or inability to move fingers, indicating nerve ischemia. Management of ACS: 1. Monitor closely for symptoms of compartment syndrome (Severe pain, swelling, numbness, tingling, muscle weakness). 2. Measure Compartment Pressure If pressure is below 20 mm Hg : Conservative management. If pressure is between 20-30 mmHg : Monitor closely for worsening. If pressure is above 30 mm Hg or Delta P is less than 30 mm Hg : Proceed to fasciotomy. 3. Conservative Management (If pressure < 20 mm Hg or borderline) Elevate limb to heart level - helps reduce edema and venous congestion without compromising arterial inflow. Remove tight dressings or splints. Monitor pain, swelling, and sensation. Repeat compartment pressure measurements regularly. Optimize blood pressure and hydration. 4. Monitor for Progression If symptoms worsen or pressure rises above 30 mm Hg: Proceed to fasciotomy. If symptoms improve: Continue conservative measures and monitoring. 5. Fasciotomy (If pressure > 30 mm Hg or worsening clinical signs) : Volar Fasciotomy 6. Post-Fasciotomy Care - Wound care, physical therapy, and monitoring for complications (e.g., scarring or contractures). Duplex imaging (Option A) may be used in suspected vascular injury or deep vein thrombosis cases. Re-apply cast (Option B) further complicates the condition. Hence, the cause should be treated initially. Analgesics (Option D) is used only temporarily for pain relief and cannot be considered the next step to manage this case.

questions.question: After a fracture in the femoral shaft, your consultant instructs you to apply tibia traction. Which of the following will you ask the nurse to provide? 1. Thomas splint 2. K-wire 3. Steinmann pin 4. Denham's pin 5. Bohler's stirrup 6. Bohler Braun splint
questions.explanation: into the tibia following a shaft of femur fracture where 10% of body weight or 20 kg of weight is used. Bohler’s stirrup is a device that holds the Steinmann pin and is used to maintain traction. Bohler Braun splint has 3 pulleys and is used to immobilise and support lower limb fractures by maintaining traction. Instrument Images Proximal Femur Nail (PFN) The Proximal Femoral Nail (PFN) is used for closed intramedullary fixation of proximal femoral fractures. It features two proximal openings for a femoral neck lag screw and an anti-rotation screw. Indications include peritrochanteric, intertrochanteric, and subtrochanteric fractures. It is contraindicated for medial femoral neck fractures. Kuntscher Nail Used for internal fixation of femoral fractures. The nail is a hollow tube with a cloverleaf shape for rotational stability. Fixation is based on three-point fixation: at both ends and the isthmus. Each end has an "eye" for the extractor hook during removal. Nail size is determined by measuring from the greater trochanter to the lateral knee joint line and subtracting 2 cm. About 2 cm of the nail is left protruding at the trochanter for removal, usually 2 years post-operation. Kirschner wire (K wire) Thin, straight steel wire with a diameter of 1 to 3 mm. Uses include: Internal fixation of small bones. Tension band wiring in patella Applying traction (e.g., through the olecranon). Fixing fractures in children. Used in Ilizarov’s fixation system. Steinmann Pin Stout, straight steel rod with a diameter of 3 to 6 mm. Primarily used for skeletal traction. Common sites for insertion include the upper end of the tibia, the supracondylar region of the femur, and the calcaneum. Bohler’s Stirrup A device used for holding a Steinmann pin and applying traction. Side screws secure the pin in place. Allows for changing the direction of traction without moving the pin inside the bone. Helps avoid loosening of the pin during traction adjustments. Thomas Splint: Primarily for the stabilization and immobilization of fractures in the femur or tibia. It consists of a metal frame that supports the limb, preventing movement and reducing the risk of further injury. Steinmann Pin: It is a large, stainless steel pin used for internal fixation of fractures or to stabilize bones during surgery. Typically inserted percutaneously (through the skin) or during surgery and is used to hold bones in place for proper healing. Denham's Pin: It is used for joint stabilization, often in the hip joint. It is inserted into the bone and can be used for traction or temporary stabilization while healing. Bohler-Braun Splint: Splint used for the immobilization of fractures, especially in the thigh and leg. It is a two-piece splint made of metal and is commonly used for fractures of the femur and tibia.

questions.question: Following a road traffic accident, a patient develops type IIIa compound tibial fracture. Arrange the following external fixators in decreasing order of their stability (highest to lowest) 1. Ilizarov fixator 2. Uniplanar with a single rod 3. Uniplanar with double rod 4. Biplanar frame/Ring with a cylindrical rod
questions.explanation: Ilizarov > Biplanar frame > Uniplanar with double rod > Uniplanar with a single rod. Ilizarov fixator : The Ilizarov fixator is the most stable fixator. It uses a ring-based system with multiple rods and wires that provide a high degree of stability and control over the alignment and position of the bone fragments. The fixator can be adjusted in multiple planes, providing more stability and making it effective for complex fractures like type IIIa compound tibial fractures. Biplanar frame/Ring with a cylindrical rod : This fixator provides stability through its ring configuration, with the added benefit of a cylindrical rod that increases strength. The biplanar design gives good stabilization in two planes, making it more stable than uniplanar designs but less so than the Ilizarov. Uniplanar with double rod : A uniplanar fixator with double rods provides more stability than a single rod because of the additional support, but it only stabilizes in one plane. It's less stable than biplanar or Ilizarov systems due to the reduced number of support structures and limited planes of control. Uniplanar with a single rod : This is the least stable option because it provides minimal support and only in one plane. It’s commonly used for less complex fractures but doesn’t offer the same level of stability needed for more severe fractures like a type IIIa compound tibial fracture.

questions.question: A 15-year-old boy was brought to the ER following a motor vehicle collision complaining of pain over the hip. The x-ray is given below. What will be the next step of management?

options.A: Closed reduction and assessment of hip stability
options.D: Open reduction and reconstruction of posterior pillar of acetabulum

questions.explanation: shows characteristics of posterior dislocation of the left hip. Deformity observed is flexion, adduction, and internal rotation of the hip. Closed reduction is a non-surgical technique to realign the displaced bone to its normal position. Posterior dislocation of hip Anterior dislocation of hip Mechanism of injury: Caused by force along the femoral shaft with the hip flexed (e.g., dashboard injury in motor accidents). Mechanism of injury: Rare injury that occurs with forced abduction and external rotation. Clinical Features: History of trauma. Pain, swelling. Deformity: flexion , adduction , internal rotation . Shortening of the leg. Femoral head is palpable in the gluteal region. Radiological Features: Femoral head displaced from the acetabulum. The thigh is internally rotated, the lesser trochanter is not seen, and Shenton’s line is broken. May require a CT scan for associated fractures. Clinical features: The limb appears externally rotated. Possible lengthening of the affected limb The femoral head is palpable in the groin . Management of posterior hip dislocation: Immediate Reduction: Reduction must be performed as soon as possible as delays over 6 hours increase risks of osteonecrosis and osteoarthritis. Closed reduction is preferred unless a femoral neck fracture is present. CT pelvis with 3D reconstruction (Option B) can give a better view of the structures around the hip joint and help detect associated fractures. Not used for first line management High-weight skeletal traction (Option C) The immediate next step of managing posterior hip dislocation would be closed reduction initially, followed by traction for 3 weeks. Open reduction and reconstruction of the posterior pillar of the acetabulum (Option D) Open reduction is an invasive procedure, and hence it is required only if closed reduction is unsuccessful or if there is a loose intra-articular fragment which prevents proper reduction, or if the acetabular fragment is large.

questions.question: What is the probable diagnosis for a patient who is brought to the hospital after a road traffic accident, complaining of pain around the left hip joint, and is found to have a flexed, adducted, and internally rotated affected limb with noticeable shortening?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Posterior hip dislocation Explanation: The scenario here points to the diagnosis of posterior dislocation of the hip , which presents the affected limb as internally rotated, adducted, flexed, and shortened. Classification of the dislocations of the hip: Posterior dislocation: the most common type, often associated with acetabular lip fracture. Anterior dislocation: rare, typically due to forced abduction and external rotation. Central fracture-dislocation: the femoral head is driven through the acetabulum into the pelvic cavity. Posterior dislocation of hip (Option B) Anterior dislocation of hip (Option A) Central fracture-dislocation of hip (Option C) Mechanism of injury: Caused by force along the femoral shaft with the hip flexed (e.g., dashboard injury in motor accidents). Mechanism of injury: Rare injury that occurs with forced abduction and external rotation. Mechanism of injury: The femoral head is driven through the medial wall of the acetabulum into the pelvic cavity. Clinical Features: History of trauma. Pain, swelling. Deformity: flexion , adduction , internal rotation . Shortening of the leg. Femoral head is palpable in the gluteal region. Clinical features: The limb appears externally rotated. Possible lengthening of the affected limb The femoral head is palpable in the groin . Clinical features: Varying displacement is seen. Joint stiffness and osteoarthritis are very likely.

questions.question: Which zone demonstrates the most optimal healing in the repair of a meniscal tear?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Red zone Explanation: The red zone of the meniscus, which has a good blood supply, also exhibits the best healing potential. Meniscal repair" data-author="" data-hash="12317" data-license="" data-source="" data-tags="May2025" src="https://image.prepladder.com/notes/ePN74UlRFNngCnji5Fok1746601931.png" /> Meniscal tears are common knee injuries that often require surgical repair. The meniscus is a C-shaped cartilage structure located in the knee joint, providing stability, load distribution, and shock absorption. The meniscus is divided into different zones based on its vascularity and healing potential. The red-white zone , where the vascular and avascular portions of the meniscus meet, has a good healing potential. The red zone is the outermost region of the meniscus and has a good blood supply, allowing for the best healing capacity. The white zone is the innermost region of the meniscus and has a poor blood supply, limiting its healing potential. Repairing a meniscal tear in the red-white zone has the highest likelihood of successful healing due to the presence of a good blood supply. Surgical techniques used for meniscal repair include suturing, meniscal fixation devices, and meniscal transplantation. Postoperative rehabilitation and physical therapy are crucial for optimal recovery and functional outcomes. Reference: Meniscal tear

questions.question: What could be the potential diagnosis for a 22-year-old male patient presenting with a history of accident, exhibiting leg abduction and external rotation?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Anterior dislocation of the hip Explanation: Anterior hip dislocation Classification Type I: Pubic (superior) injuries Type II: Obturator (inferior) injuries Management Reduction should be performed as soon as possible under sedation or general anesthesia. Closed reduction technique: Hold the affected leg in external rotation, abduction, and flexion. Apply longitudinal traction. Internally and externally rotate the leg until reduction is achieved, and apply anterior pressure on the femoral head if necessary. If repeated attempts fail, consider an open reduction. Complications Injury to the sciatic nerve. Avascular necrosis of the femoral head : may require hip replacement if osteoarthritis develops. Osteoarthritis : develops years later. Treatment varies from conservative to total hip replacement. Myositis Ossificans : Develops weeks to months post-injury and is characterized by pain and stiffness. Ill-advised vigorous and improper massage following trauma is the most common cause.Treatment includes rest and analgesics. Potential for associated femoral head fractures. Posterior dislocation of hip (Option B ruled out) Anterior dislocation of hip Central fracture-dislocation of hip Mechanism of injury: Caused by force along the femoral shaft with the hip flexed (e.g., dashboard injury in motor accidents). Mechanism of injury: Rare injury that occurs with forced abduction and external rotation. Mechanism of injury: The femoral head is driven through the medial wall of the acetabulum into the pelvic cavity. Clinical Features: History of trauma. Pain, swelling. Deformity: flexion , adduction , internal rotation . Shortening of the leg. Femoral head is palpable in the gluteal region. Radiological Features: Femoral head displaced from the acetabulum. The thigh is internally rotated, the lesser trochanter is not seen, and Shenton’s line is broken. May require a CT scan for associated fractures. Clinical features: The limb appears externally rotated. Possible lengthening of the affected limb The femoral head is palpable in the groin . Clinical features: Varying displacement is seen. Joint stiffness and osteoarthritis are very likely. An Intertrochanteric fracture (Option C) is a fracture of the femur that occurs between the greater and lesser trochanter. It typically presents with pain and inability to bear weight , but not necessarily with leg abduction and external rotation. This injury is usually associated with falls or trauma but doesn't typically cause the specific positioning of the leg seen in dislocations. A fracture of the femoral neck (Option D) typically presents with shortening , external rotation , and abduction of the leg, but this injury is more commonly seen in elderly patients with osteoporosis, particularly following falls. While there can be external rotation, abduction is more characteristic of a posterior dislocation or intertrochanteric fracture rather than a femoral neck fracture.

questions.question: What is the probable diagnosis for a patient who was admitted to the intensive care unit 48 hours after fracturing their femur, with a saturation of oxygen in the rebreathing unit at 100%, but their SpO 2 remained at 60%? The patient is also experiencing confusion, and a chest radiograph shows clear lung fields.
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Fat embolism Explanation: The most likely diagnosis is Fat Embolism due to the combination of confusion, petechial rash, tachycardia, tachypnea, and low oxygen saturation following a femur fracture. Fat Embolism Fat embolism is a multi-organ disorder caused by fat globules entering the bloodstream, commonly occurring after high-risk orthopedic injuries, particularly femur fractures. Classic Triad Hypoxia Petechiae Altered mental status Other Symptoms Tachycardia, fever, anemia, thrombocytopenia, pulmonary dysfunction (e.g., tachypnea, respiratory acidosis). Etiology Young adults (20-30 years): Long bone fractures Iatrogenic cause: Occurs after intramedullary (IM) nailing of the femur. Pathogenesis Following injury, fat from bone marrow or platelet agglutination enters injured vessels and travels as emboli, leading to various clinical manifestations. Investigation Chest X-ray: Commonly clear lung fields, occasionally Snowstorm appearance is seen (pathognomonic) PaO I <60 mm Hg Platelet count <1.5 lakhs ECG: Prominent S-wave Other lab findings: Anemia, hypocalcemia CT scan and MRI: Assess severity Management Respiratory support: Oxygen or ventilator support to restore PaO I Drug therapy: Steroids: Reduce lung inflammation and improve gas exchange. Heparin: Lipolytic and antiplatelet agent. Low molecular weight dextran: Increases plasma volume. Antibiotics and other supportive care. Definitive fracture treatment: Early fixation to prevent worsening. Incorrect Options: Pulmonary Embolism (Option B): typically presents with sudden onset dyspnea, chest pain, and tachycardia, but lacks the petechial rash and altered mental status seen in this case. Additionally, the patient's history of femur fracture points more strongly to fat embolism rather than pulmonary embolism. ARDS (Option C): typically presents with sudden onset breathlessness associated with hypoxemia and diffuse alveolar infiltrates on x-ray. Occult Pneumothorax (Option D): presents with pleuritic chest pain and absent breath sounds, which differs from the petechial rash and altered mental status seen in fat embolism, especially after femur fractures.

questions.question: In the case of an ongoing bleeding in a patient with a fracture of the pelvic bone, what is the immediate action that needs to be taken to address the situation, if the patient is in hypotension?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Crystalloids Explanation: In a case of pelvic bone fracture with hypotension, the immediate next step will be to administer crystalloids and stabilise the patient. Management steps to be followed in this patient: Assessment of vital signs and initiation of ATLS protocol - administration of crystalloids. Pelvic binder is applied to reduce bleeding and maintain hemostasis. (Option D) An external fixator is then applied until the patient's hemodynamic status is stable, followed by internal definite fixation once the patient is fit for surgery. Complications and Management of Pelvic fracture: Shock: Hemorrhagic shock from pelvic injury is the most common cause of mortality (30%). Management: Initial Management: Primary survey (ABCDE) and simultaneous resuscitation as per Advanced Trauma Life Support (ATLS) guidelines. (Option A) Laparotomy: Immediate laparotomy if the patient remains unstable. Preperitoneal Packing (PPP): Used to create a tamponade effect. Resuscitative Endovascular Balloon Occlusion of the Aorta (REBOA): Uses balloon catheter to occlude the aorta in life-threatening hemorrhage ; Can be inflated for up to 60 minutes ; Intermittent inflation helps with resuscitation and reduces reperfusion injury. Surgical Fixation for Unstable Pelvic Fractures: External Fixation: Provides initial stabilization, particularly in hemodynamically unstable patients. Pins are placed in the iliac wings or anterior inferior iliac spine. (Option B) Definitive Repair: Undertaken once the patient is stable ; Various techniques include anterior symphyseal plating, ORIF of the ilium, or sacroiliac screw placement depending on the fracture type. (Option C) Urethral Injuries: More common in males, with the membranous urethra being the most commonly affected site. Rupture can be complete or incomplete, partial or full thickness. Cardinal signs of urethral injury: Blood at the urethral meatus, perineal hematoma, distended bladder. Treatment: Drainage of the bladder via suprapubic cystostomy. Micturating cysto-urethrogram after 6 weeks to assess for urethral stricture, followed by appropriate treatment. Bladder Injuries: Extraperitoneal injuries are treated nonoperatively. Intraperitoneal injuries require surgical repair. Sigmoid and Rectal Injuries: Intraperitoneal injuries are debrided and primarily repaired if possible. Extraperitoneal rectal injuries are managed with primary repair and diverting colostomy. Vaginal Lacerations: First-degree injuries are treated with gauze packing; second- and third-degree injuries require surgical repair.

questions.question: A 35-year-old patient presents with complaints of back pain, stiffness, and recurrent episodes of eye pain with redness. On examination, they are found to have anterior uveitis and sacroiliitis. Which of the following HLA is commonly involved
questions.explanation: Correct answer: C) HLA B27 Explanation: The clinical scenario of back pain, stiffness, anterior uveitis and sacroiliitis. Ankylosing Spondylitis (AS) / Marie Strumpell Disease Definition Chronic inflammatory disease primarily affecting the axial skeleton (spine and sacroiliac joints), leading to pain, stiffness, and spinal fusion (bamboo spine) . Etiology Unknown; genetic (HLA-B27 ) and environmental factors involved. HLA-B27 is positive in 90% of cases, but not all carriers develop AS. Pathophysiology Inflammation at entheses → Erosive changes → New bone formation → Syndesmophytes → Spinal fusion (ankylosis). Clinical Features Musculoskeletal Symptoms: Chronic low back pain (worse after inactivity, better with activity) Limited spinal mobility Enthesitis (Achilles, plantar fascia) Peripheral arthritis (hips, shoulders, knees) Extra-articular Symptoms: Ocular: Anterior uveitis (pain, redness, photophobia) Cardiovascular: Aortic regurgitation, conduction issues Pulmonary: Apical fibrosis Gastrointestinal: Associated with IBD Diagnosis Based on clinical features, imaging studies, and HLA-B27 gene presence. Modified New York Criteria: Clinical Criteria: Low back pain > 3 months (improves with exercise, not with rest) Limited lumbar spine motion (sagittal/frontal planes) Reduced chest expansion (relative to age/sex) Radiographic Criteria (X-ray): Bilateral sacroiliitis (grade 2-4) or unilateral sacroiliitis (grade 3-4) Radiological Features: Blurring/haziness of sacroiliac joint Juxta-articular sclerosis Vertical/bridging syndesmophytes Squaring of vertebrae Bamboo spine Trolley track sign Dagger sign Shiny corner sign/Romanus lesion (inflammatory lesions at edges of vertebrae) MRI: Early detection of inflammation Clinical Tests: For Sacroiliitis: Gaenslen’s test Patrick/FABER test Figure of 4 test Pump handle test For Lumbar Spine: Schober/ Modified Schober test Laboratory Tests HLA-B27 positive (90% of cases) ESR, CRP: Elevated during active disease, but can be normal Differential Diagnosis Mechanical low back pain Other spondyloarthropathies (e.g., psoriatic arthritis) Degenerative disc disease Fibromyalgia Treatment Non-Pharmacological: Physical therapy (mobility/posture exercises) Patient education on disease and exercise importance Pharmacological: NSAIDs (first-line for pain, stiffness) TNF inhibitors (for NSAID-resistant cases) IL-17 inhibitors (Secukinumab) Sulfasalazine (for peripheral arthritis) Corticosteroids (short-term flare control) Surgical: Hip replacement (for severe hip involvement) Spinal surgery (for severe deformities/fractures) Complications Spinal fractures (minimal trauma) Cardiac issues (aortic regurgitation, conduction defects) Osteoporosis leading to fracture risk

questions.question: A 30-year-old met with a bike accident and presented with the following finding. What is the diagnosis?
questions.explanation: anterior hip dislocation. Classification of the dislocations of the hip: Posterior dislocation: the most common type, often associated with acetabular lip fracture. Anterior dislocation: rare, typically due to forced abduction and external rotation. Central fracture-dislocation: the femoral head is driven through the acetabulum into the pelvic cavity. Posterior dislocation of hip Anterior dislocation of hip Central fracture-dislocation of hip Mechanism of injury: Caused by force along the femoral shaft with the hip flexed (e.g., dashboard injury in motor accidents). Mechanism of injury: Rare injury that occurs with forced abduction and external rotation. Mechanism of injury: The femoral head is driven through the medial wall of the acetabulum into the pelvic cavity. Clinical Features: History of trauma. Pain, swelling. Deformity: flexion , adduction , internal rotation . Shortening of the leg. Femoral head is palpable in the gluteal region. Radiological Features: Femoral head displaced from the acetabulum. The thigh is internally rotated, the lesser trochanter is not seen, and Shenton’s line is broken. May require a CT scan for associated fractures. Clinical features: The limb appears externally rotated. Possible lengthening of the affected limb The femoral head is palpable in the groin . Clinical features: Varying displacement is seen. Joint stiffness and osteoarthritis are very likely. Posterior Hip Dislocation (Option B): Would present with flexion, adduction, and internal rotation (not seen here). Superior Hip Dislocation (Option C): Very rare, associated with high-energy trauma and pelvic fractures. Both A and B (Option D): The presentation is specific to anterior dislocation only.

questions.question: Identify the orthopedic implant shown in the image
questions.explanation: designed for the fixation of intertrochanteric fractures of the femur. It consists of a large screw that is inserted into the femoral head and a side plate that is fixed to the femoral shaft. The "dynamic" feature allows for controlled collapse of the fracture, promoting healing. Adynamic Hip Screw (Option B) This term is incorrect or non-existent in orthopedic practice. Condylar Hip Screw (Option C) This implant is used for fixing fractures around the distal femur, specifically the condylar region. It is not used for intertrochanteric fractures of the proximal femur. Intramedullary Nail (Option D) is a long metal rod inserted into the medullary cavity of long bones, commonly used for diaphyseal fractures. It is not typically used for intertrochanteric femur fractures, although some variations (like a cephalomedullary nail) may be used in cases.

questions.question: A patient presents with 5th metatarsal fracture. For how many days he/she would have to wear cast?
questions.explanation: allows adequate time for bone healing, considering the location and nature of the fracture. This duration helps ensure proper alignment and support, leading to better outcomes. Incorrect Options Options A,B and D are incorrect as given above

questions.question: A heavy lifter presents with lower back ache. Identify the nerve compressed in the following disc prolapse?
questions.explanation: individuals who lift heavy weights. The L5 nerve root can be compressed by a prolapsed disc, leading to lower back pain, pain radiating down the posterior thigh, lateral aspect of the leg, and weakness in dorsiflexion of the foot (difficulty lifting the foot). Incorrect Options: Option A - L4 : A disc prolapse affecting the L4 nerve root is less common. Compression at this level can cause symptoms such as pain and weakness in the anterior thigh and knee area, but typically, lower back pain from heavy lifting is more often associated with the L5 or S1 nerve roots. Option C - S1 : Although the S1 nerve root can also be affected by disc prolapse, it typically results in pain and weakness in the posterior leg and plantar aspect of the foot. The S1 nerve root compression is less common in heavy lifters compared to L5. Option D - S4 : Compression of the S4 nerve root is rare in cases of disc prolapse and is usually associated with issues in the sacral region. Symptoms related to S4 would include pelvic and

questions.question: A man presents with back pain following road traffic accident. There was no history of neurological deficit. X ray spine is done. What is the diagnosis?
questions.explanation: projection off the back of a vertebra is broken. Hyperextension injuries typically cause this type of fracture and often presents with localized back pain without neurological deficits. X-rays show a fracture of the spinous process, but the vertebral body remains intact as given in the image. Incorrect options: Option B - Chance Fracture: A Chance fracture, also known as a seatbelt fracture, is a type of spinal injury caused by hyperflexion of the spine, often associated with a lap belt during a car accident. It is characterized by a fracture through the vertebral body and posterior elements. On X-ray, it shows a horizontal fracture line through the vertebral body, which might be difficult to identify if only the spinous process is imaged. Option C - Fracture of the Base of Vertebrae: This type of fracture involves a break at the base of the vertebra, which could affect the anterior or posterior aspects of the vertebra. It may not always present with neurological symptoms immediately but could

questions.question: Which area is affected by the fracture shown in the given X-ray?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A. Tibial tuberosity fracture The lateral X-ray of the knee joint clearly shows a fracture involving the tibial tuberosity , which is the bony prominence on the anterior surface of the tibia just below the patella. This is the insertion site for the patellar tendon , and fractures here are usually seen in adolescents during forceful quadriceps contraction (e.g., jumping sports). Features of Tibial Tuberosity Fracture: Feature Description Location Anterior proximal tibia (tibial tuberosity) Mechanism Forceful contraction of quadriceps (e.g., jumping, kicking) Radiograph finding Fracture through or below the tibial tuberosity Associated conditions May be associated with Osgood-Schlatter disease as a predisposing factor Medial epicondyle of tibia (Option B): Incorrect — the fracture is not located medially; it's clearly anterior and involves the tibial tuberosity. Gerdy's tubercle fracture (Option C): Incorrect — Gerdy's tubercle is lateral, where the iliotibial band inserts . The fracture here is not lateral. Osgood-Schlatter disease (Option D): Incorrect — this is a chronic traction apophysitis , not an acute fracture. It causes pain and swelling , not a well-defined fracture line.

questions.question: A 55-year-old female presented with back pain for six months. Her CT scan image is given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: the one below it, usually due to degeneration, trauma, or congenital defects. The CT scan in this case would show the misalignment of the vertebrae, explaining the patient's chronic back pain. This diagnosis is consistent with the clinical presentation and imaging findings. Incorrect Options: Option A - Paget's Disease: Paget’s disease is a chronic bone disorder that can cause enlarged and deformed bones. On imaging, it typically shows thickened cortical bone, enlarged bones with mixed lytic and sclerotic changes, and a characteristic “cotton wool” appearance. This disease usually affects the pelvis, skull, spine, and long bones, but the imaging features would differ from those seen in spondylolisthesis. Option B - Osteoporosis: Osteoporosis leads to decreased bone density and increased fracture risk, especially in the spine, hips, and wrists. CT scans of patients with osteoporosis typically show generalized bone thinning, with possible compression fractures in the vertebrae, but not the characteristic vertebral slippage seen in spondylolisthesis. Option D - Renal Osteodystrophy: This is a bone pathology associated with chronic kidney disease, characterized by alterations in bone morphology. Imaging might show subperiosteal resorption, "rugger-jersey" spine, or osteosclerosis, but it would not show the vertebral slippage characteristic of spondylolisthesis.

questions.question: A patient suffers an inversion injury to the ankle. Which structure is most likely to get injured?
questions.explanation: commonly injured structure in an inversion injury, as it is the weakest of the lateral ligaments and is directly stressed by inversion movements. The peroneus longus tendon, which helps evert the foot, can also be affected due to the force of the inversion. Incorrect Options: Option A - Tibialis anterior tendon: This tendon primarily functions to dorsiflex and invert the foot. While it plays a role in ankle stability, it is not typically injured in an inversion injury, which stresses the lateral ligaments rather than the anterior structures. Option B - Tibialis posterior tendon: This tendon is responsible for foot inversion and support of the medial arch. Injuries to the tibialis posterior tendon are more associated with overuse or medial stress rather than acute inversion injuries, which typically affect the lateral side of the ankle. Option C - Extensor hallucis longus tendon: This tendon controls the extension of the big toe and assists in dorsiflexion of the foot. It is less commonly injured in inversion sprains, as it is not located in the lateral or medial regions of the ankle that bear the brunt of an inversion force. Reference: Textbook of orthopedics, John Ebnezar, Rakesh John, 5th Edition- Page 265

questions.question: Identify the type of fracture in a patient who sustained a road traffic accident resulting in fractures of both the tibia and fibula.
questions.explanation: tibial plateau fracture, which commonly occurs in road traffic accidents. This type of fracture often involves both the tibia and fibula. Classification of Tibial Plateau Fracture The tibial plateau refers to the proximal tibial surface, which comprises the medial and lateral articular surfaces of the respective tibial condyles. Lateral tibial plateau fractures are the most common. Mechanism of Injury The main mechanism of injury is a varus or valgus force, with or without axial load. Young Adults: Road traffic accidents, leading to split fractures (high ligament injury risk). Elderly: Trivial falls, causing depression or split depression fractures (associated with osteoporosis) (low ligament injury risk). Classification (Schatzker) Type I: Lateral plateau split fracture (young adults). Type II: Lateral plateau split depression (young adults). Type III: Lateral plateau pure depression (elderly). Type IV: Medial plateau fracture. Type V: Bicondylar fracture. Type VI: Dissociation of metaphysis and diaphysis. Clinical Features Knee swelling due to hemarthrosis. Inability to bear weight Reduce range of knee movements Compartment syndrome (earliest sign: stretch pain ). Imaging X-ray: Initial fracture detection. CT with 3D Reconstruction: Gold standard. MRI: To assess ligament injuries. Management Non-surgical: Stable fractures with minimal displacement. Surgical (ORIF): For displaced fractures or significant depression. Ligament reconstruction if needed. Patella sleeve fracture (Options B) This injury generally occurs from direct trauma to the front of the knee or from a fall, and while possible in road traffic accidents, it is less likely in this case where the deformity and mechanism suggest lateral tibial plateau involvement. Depressed skull fracture (Options C) Typically caused by small objects impacting the skull at high velocity. Cervical fracture (Options D) do not involve fracture of both tibia and fibula.

questions.question: A 75-year-old man presents with a fracture of the intracapsular neck of the femur. What is the standard management done in this patient?
questions.explanation: of femur , blood supply to the femoral head is often compromised. This leads to a high risk of avascular necrosis and nonunion , making internal fixation less favorable. Hemiarthroplasty (replacement of the femoral head) is the standard treatment to allow early mobilization and reduce complications like bedsores, pneumonia, and DVT. Fracture Neck of Femur Aspect Details Common in Elderly, especially osteoporotic bones Type of fracture Intracapsular (femoral neck, within joint capsule) Risk Disruption of blood supply → avascular necrosis Goal of treatment Restore mobility, minimize complications of immobility Preferred treatment (elderly) Hemiarthroplasty – replacement of femoral head Preferred treatment (young) Internal fixation with cannulated screws or DHS Boot and bar cast (Option B): Incorrect because casting is not effective for femoral neck fractures in adults and leads to prolonged immobilization and complications. Intramedullary nails (Option C): Incorrect because these are used for shaft or intertrochanteric fractures , not for intracapsular neck fractures. Russell’s traction (Option D): Incorrect as it is outdated and not standard in current practice; it delays mobilization and increases complication risk. Reference: Campbell’s Operative Orthopedics, Volume-1, 14th Edition, Page 201 https://www.sciencedirect.com/topics/medicine-and-dentistry/hemiarthroplasty#

questions.question: Which of he following layer is affected in a Salter-Harris type 1 fracture ?

options.A: Calcific zone of the growth plate
options.B: Hypertrophic zone of the growth plate
options.C: The resting zone of the growth plate
options.D: Through the whole of the epiphysis

questions.explanation: separation of metaphysis and epiphysis without fracture. Apart from trauma, it is common in rickets, scurvy, osteomyelitis. The hypertrophic layer is involved. Incorrect Options: Options A, C & D are incorrect as the hypertrophic layer ( weakest layer)is affected in Salter-Harris type 1 fracture Reference: .

questions.question: A 26-year-old male presented with a proximal 1/3rd fracture of shaft of femur. What is the treatment of choice in this patient?
questions.explanation: shaft fractures in adults, providing stability via a frictional fit within the medullary canal and interlocking screws that anchor the bone to the nail. This method offers better control over length and torsion than unlocked nails. Incorrect Options: Options B, C & D: In fractures occurring in the proximal one-third of the femoral shaft, vigorous muscle contractions can lead to significant displacement of the fracture. Consequently, traditional immobilization methods such as hip spica, above knee slab, and above knee cast may not effectively maintain alignment. Reference: .

questions.question: In a 70-year-old female who presents with extracapsular neck of femur fracture, what is the treatment of choice in this condition?
questions.explanation: in which the vascularity is intact therefore intramedullary nailing is done to prevent malunion/coxa vara. Incorrect Options: Option A - Hemi arthroplasty: This is done in case of disrupted vascularity resulting in avascular necrosis or non-union Option B - Boot and bar cast: This is done as a conservative management for the inoperable patients. Option D - Russell's traction: This is mainly used for temporary stabilization and pain relief before definitive surgery, not as a definitive treatment. Reference: .

questions.question: The diagnosis in a patient who is unable to do internal and external rotation of the hip is?
questions.explanation: dislocation of the hip is flexed, adducted and fully internally rotated which makes it impossible for further internal or external rotation of the hip. Posterior dislocation of hip Anterior dislocation of hip Mechanism of injury: Caused by force along the femoral shaft with the hip flexed (e.g., dashboard injury in motor accidents). Mechanism of injury: Rare injury that occurs with forced abduction and external rotation. Clinical Features: History of trauma. Pain, swelling. Deformity: flexion , adduction , internal rotation . Shortening of the leg. Femoral head is palpable in the gluteal region. Radiological Features: Femoral head displaced from the acetabulum. The thigh is internally rotated, the lesser trochanter is not seen, and Shenton’s line is broken. May require a CT scan for associated fractures. Clinical features: The limb appears externally rotated. Possible lengthening of the affected limb The femoral head is palpable in the groin . Femur Head Fracture (Option A) may affect hip movement, it doesn't specifically cause a loss of both internal and external rotation as prominently as a dislocation Acetabular Fractures (Option B) may not result in an absolute inability to perform internal and external rotation unless they are associated with significant displacement or damage to the surrounding structures. Pelvic Fracture (Option D does not typically cause a complete loss of internal and external rotation of the hip, unless there is concurrent injury to the hip joint itself.

questions.question: Which muscle is attached to lesser trochanter?
questions.explanation: and function: Hip Flexor Muscle Origin Attachment Function Iliopsoas (Psoas major + Iliacus) Psoas major: Transverse processes of T12-L5 vertebrae Iliacus: Iliac fossa of the pelvis Both muscles combine and attach at the lesser trochanter of the femur Primary hip flexor Flexion of the hip joint Assists in trunk flexion (psoas) Rectus Femoris Anterior inferior iliac spine (AIIS) and acetabulum Tibial tuberosity via the patellar tendon Flexion of the hip Extends the knee Sartorius Anterior superior iliac spine (ASIS) Medial surface of the tibia (Pes anserinus) Flexion, abduction, and lateral rotation of the hip Flexion of the knee Tensor Fasciae Latae (TFL) Anterior part of the iliac crest Anterior superior iliac spine (ASIS) Iliotibial band (ITB), which attaches to the lateral condyle of the tibia Flexion and abduction of the hip Medial rotation of the hip Pectineus Pectineal line of the pubis Pectineal line of the femur Flexion and adduction of the hip Adductor Longus Pubic bone near the pubic symphysis Medial linea aspera of the femur Flexion of the hip (when the hip is in extension) Adduction of the hip Psoas minor (Option B) Inserted into the illiopectinal eminence Innervated by the anterior rami of L1, 2 Flexes the thigh Obturator internus (Option C) Inserted into greater trochanter of the femur Innervated by the nerve to obturator internus (L5, S1) Laterally rotates extended thigh and abducts flexed hip Piriformis (Option A) Inserts superiorly into the tip of the greater trochanter. Innervated by the branches of anterior rami (S1, S2) Laterally rotates extended thigh and abducts flexed hip

questions.question: A patient presents in the OPD after a road traffic accident complaining of being unable to dorsiflex and evert the ankle. A X- ray was ordered by the attending physician. In addition to the observed injury on the X-ray, which gait abnormality is likely to be present in this patient?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Stepping gait Explanation: X-ray shows fracture-neck of fibula , Common peroneal nerve injury is common as it winds around the neck of fibula - which leads to Foot drop (inability to dorsiflex/evert the ankle). Stepping gait is commonly seen in patients with foot drop. X-Ray showing Fibular neck fracture Common peroneal nerve injury: Anatomy: The terminal branch of the sciatic nerve arises from the popliteal fossa. Root value: L4,L5,S1 & S2. Hooks around the neck of the fibula. Terminates by dividing into Superficial peroneal nerve & Deep peroneal nerve Muscles supplied: Superficial peroneal nerve: Peroneus longus & brevis (foot eversion) Deep peroneal nerve: Peroneus tertius, Tibialis anterior, Extensor digitorum, Extensor

questions.question: A child presents to the orthopedic OPD with a limp and limb shortening . His X-ray is given below, What is the diagnosis?
Given below is the X ray of a newborn. What is the type of scoliosis shown in the X-ray ?
questions.explanation: abnormal spinal development during fetal development. Incorrect Options: Option B - Postural Scoliosis: Also known as non-structural scoliosis, this type of scoliosis is reversible and typically caused by factors such as poor posture, muscle imbalances, or leg length discrepancy. It does not involve any structural abnormalities of the spine. Option C - Infantile Scoliosis: This type of scoliosis develops in children younger than three years old. The cause is often unknown, and it can spontaneously resolve or progress over time. Option D - Degenerative Scoliosis: Also known as adult-onset scoliosis, this type of scoliosis occurs later in life due to degenerative changes in the spine, such as disc degeneration, osteoporosis, or spinal arthritis. Reference: Prepladder Notes

questions.question: A 55-year-old female patient came with a flexion contracture of the hip. Which of the following test is useful in diagnosis?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Thomas test Explanation: Thomas test: The Thomas test is specifically designed to detect hip flexion contracture . The patient lies supine, and one hip is maximally flexed to flatten the lumbar spine and stabilize the pelvis. If the opposite leg lifts off the table (instead of staying flat), it indicates a flexion contracture of the contralateral hip. It is commonly used in elderly patients or individuals with hip arthritis or postural abnormalities. Thomas test is the most appropriate and specific clinical test to diagnose hip flexion contracture . Allen’s test (Option A): Is used to assess arterial blood flow to the hand, especially the patency of the radial and ulnar arteries before arterial blood gas sampling or cannulation. Not related to hip joint pathology. Trendelenburg test (Option B): Assesses the integrity of the hip abductor muscles , particularly the gluteus medius and minimus. A positive test indicates weakness or instability in these muscles (e.g., due to superior gluteal nerve injury), not a flexion contracture. Ober test (Option D): Used to detect iliotibial band (IT band) tightness or contracture. The patient lies on the unaffected side, and the examiner extends and abducts the affected leg, then allows it to drop. If it remains elevated, it suggests IT band tightness. Not specific for hip flexion contracture.

questions.question: Which of the following is true regarding the scar tissue in patellar clunk syndrome?

options.A: Superior pole of the patella, impinging during flexion
options.B: Superior pole of the patella, impinging during extension
options.C: Inferior pole of the patella, impinging during flexion
options.D: Inferior pole of the patella, impinging during extension

questions.explanation: (PCS) is attributed to the formation of a fibrous nodule at the junction of the proximal (superior) patellar pole and the articular aspect of the quadriceps tendon. This nodule becomes entrapped in the intercondylar box of the femoral component during knee flexion. Upon knee extension to 30-45 degrees, the nodule suddenly dislodges, resulting in a painful audible clunk Incorrect Options: Options A, B, and D are incorrect and the correct option is explained above. Reference: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC7732733/ Prepladder Notes

questions.question: A 79 yrs old lady had a fall in the bathroom, the following X-rays were taken in order to make a diagnosis . Which of the following is treatment of this condition?
Blount Disease results from the involvement of
questions.explanation: that primarily affects the proximal tibia Main symptoms include noticeable leg bowing, leg pain, walking difficulty, and an abnormal gait. Diagnosis involves physical examination and imaging tests like X-rays. Treatment depends on age, severity, and complications, with options ranging from bracing and physical therapy to surgery for severe cases. Incorrect Options: Option B - Distal Tibia: Blount Disease primarily affects the proximal tibia, not the distal tibia. Option C - Proximal Femur: Blount Disease does not involve the proximal femur. Option D - Distal Femur: Blount Disease primarily affects the proximal tibia, not the distal femur. Reference: Prepladder Notes

questions.question: A 40-year-old patient presents to the emergency department following a road traffic accident. The radiograph of his pelvis is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: displaced posteriorly from the acetabulum. It is the most common type of hip dislocation resulting from high-energy trauma, such as a road traffic accident. Mode of injury: Axial force applied to a flexed, adducted,and internally rotated hip. Example: Dashboard injury. 50% of PDH are associated with posterior chip fracture of acetabulum. Plain x-ray won't give any results. A CT scan is the investigation of choice in dislocationwith fractures. Differentiation of PDH and ADH on x-ray In ADH - Head is larger In PDH - Smaller head Incorrect Options: Option A - Central dislocation of the hip: This term is not commonly used to describe hip dislocations. Central dislocation usually refers to a type of hip joint dislocation where the femoral head is displaced centrally within the acetabulum. It is a rare condition and not typically seen in traumatic injuries. Option B - Fracture shaft of femur: This refers to a fracture along the shaft (middle portion) of the femur bone. It does not directly involve the hip joint. Option D - Anterior dislocation of the hip: This is a type of hip joint dislocation where the femoral head is displaced anteriorly (towards the front) from the acetabulum. It is less common than posterior dislocation

questions.question: Identify the shown image
questions.explanation: patellar tendon brace or patellar tendon strap, is a specialized brace designed to provide targeted support and compression to the patellar tendon. It is commonly used in conditions such as patellar tendonitis or jumper's knee, where there is pain or inflammation in the patellar tendon. Incorrect Options: Option A - Ankle Knee Stabilizer: An ankle knee stabilizer is a type of brace or support that provides stability to both the ankle and knee joints. It is commonly used in cases of ligament injuries or instability in these joints. Option C - Thomas Splint: The Thomas splint is a specific type of splint used for immobilization and stabilization of the femur or thigh bone. It is commonly used in cases of fractures or dislocations of the femur. Option D - None of the above: This option is incorrect

questions.question: Avascular necrosis of the femur head is due to which of the following artery?
questions.explanation: The MCFA is a branch of the deep femoral artery and provides the primary blood supply to the femoral head. Disruption or occlusion of this artery can lead to compromised blood flow to the femoral head, resulting in avascular necrosis. The diagnosis and management of avascular necrosis of the femoral head typically involve a combination of clinical evaluation, imaging studies (such as X-rays, MRI, or bone scans), and treatment options ranging from conservative measures to surgical interventions, depending on the severity and stage of the condition. Incorrect Options: Option B - Lateral Circumflex Femoral Artery (LCFA): The LCFA is also a branch of the deep femoral artery, but it primarily supplies blood to the muscles around the hip joint and does not directly supply the femoral head. Option C - Obturator Artery: The obturator artery primarily supplies blood to the muscles of the medial thigh and does not directly supply the femoral head. Option D: None of the above Reference: Prepladder Notes

questions.question: Football player gets blow to the outer knee during match. Which structure is most commonly associated with this type of injury?
questions.explanation: helps stabilize the knee against excessive sideways or valgus stress. It connects the femur (thigh bone) to the tibia (shin bone) and plays a crucial role in maintaining the integrity of the knee joint. When the knee undergoes a forceful impact from the outer side, such as a blow to the outer knee during sports like football, it can result in a valgus stress on the knee. This valgus force can cause the MCL to stretch or tear, resulting in an MCL injury. Incorrect options: Option A. Anterior cruciate ligament (ACL): While the ACL is another important ligament in the knee, it is not directly associated with MCL injuries. The ACL is located inside the knee joint and is responsible for controlling rotational and anterior translation of the tibia in relation to the femur. Option C . Posterior cruciate ligament (PCL): The PCL is also an internal ligament of the knee, but it is not commonly associated with MCL injuries. The PCL helps stabilize the knee against posterior translation of the tibia in relation to the femur. Option D . Lateral meniscus: The lateral meniscus is the counterpart of the medial meniscus and is located on the outer side of the knee joint. It is not directly associated with MCL injuries. However, it can be injured independently or in conjunction with other knee injuries. Reference: .

questions.question: Evaluate the following statements with respect to inter – trochanteric fracture , and opt for the correct ones : More common in males than females One – year mortality rate is about 20 to 30% It is more commonly associated with non – union than fracture neck of femur One year mortality rate can be reduced by operating within 48 hours
questions.explanation: statement is correct. The one-year mortality rate for inter-trochanteric fractures can range from 20 to 30%, depending on various factors such as the patient's age, overall health, and the presence of comorbidities. Statement 4: One-year mortality rate can be reduced by operating within 48 hours - This statement is correct. Early surgical intervention within 48 hours of the fracture has been shown to reduce the risk of complications and improve outcomes, including the mortality rate. Incorrect Options: Option A - 1 and 3 are correct: Statement 1: More common in males than females - This statement is incorrect. Inter-trochanteric fractures do not show a significant gender predilection and can occur in both males and females. Statement 3: It is more commonly associated with non-union than fracture neck of femur - This statement is incorrect. Inter-trochanteric fractures generally have a lower risk of non-union compared to fractures of the neck of the femur. Option B - 1, 2, 3 are correct: Statement 2: One-year mortality rate is about 20 to 30% - This statement is incorrect. The one-year mortality rate for inter-trochanteric fractures is typically lower than 20-30%. Option D - 1, 2, 3, 4 are correct: The correct option is C: 2 and 4 are correct. The statements regarding the one-year mortality rate and the ability to reduce mortality by operating within 48 hours are accurate, while the statements about the gender distribution and association with non-union are incorrect. Reference: Prepladder Notes

questions.question: A 34-year-old male has been suffering from a progressive lower backache and early morning stiffness for the past six months. His symptoms are more severe in the morning and improve with exercise. He is a known case of ulcerative colitis. An X-ray of his lumbar spine is given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: affecting the spine and sacroiliac joints, more common in males and starting in late teens to early adulthood. Key symptoms include morning stiffness and back pain, alleviated by exercise. Other signs may include fatigue, fever, and weight loss. It's often linked with inflammatory bowel disease, like ulcerative colitis. The characteristic "bamboo spine" appearance results from vertebrae bridging. Incorrect Options: Option A - Pott’s spine: Pott's spine, also known as tuberculosis of the spine, presents with similar symptoms to ankylosing spondylitis, but it typically affects only one or two vertebrae and can lead to vertebral collapse and deformity. Option B - Psoriatic

questions.question: A young patient presented to the emergency department with pain and swelling of the right knee . A plain radiograph is shown below. What is the best treatment for this condition?

options.B: Tension band wiring with cancellous screws

questions.explanation: patella, typically caused by direct impact, falling on a bent knee, or sudden twisting. Such fractures are common among active individuals, especially in sports-related incidents. Tension band wiring with K-wires, utilizing two K-wires and a tension band wire, stabilizes the fracture and promotes healing. Incorrect Options: Option B - Tension band wiring with cancellous screws treats displaced patellar fractures but poses risks like infection, hardware failure, and knee stiffness. Option C - Cylinder cast immobilization, used for non-displaced patellar fractures or postoperative care, involves a long-leg cast or brace from hip to ankle, promoting knee joint immobilization for healing. Option D - Patellectomy, the last resort for severe patellar fractures, involves surgical patella removal, with potential functional limitations, making it unsuitable for all cases.

questions.question: A 14-year-old patient presents to the outpatient department with a noticeable deformity of the neck and upper back. On physical examination, the patient's scapula is observed to be elevated and medially rotated, giving it the appearance of an equilateral triangle. The patient also has limited neck mobility. The patient and their family report that the deformity has been present since birth and has not improved over time. What is the likely diagnosis for this patient's condition?
questions.explanation: cervical vertebrae, resulting in a short neck and limited neck mobility. The characteristic "triangular" appearance of the neck due to scapular elevation and medial rotation is a hallmark of Klippel-Feil deformity. Incorrect options: Option A - Separated shoulder deformity: This refers to a type of shoulder injury where the acromioclavicular joint is sprained or dislocated due to trauma. Option B - Torticollis: Torticollis, also known as wry neck, is a condition characterized by the abnormal positioning or tilting of the head, often due to muscle spasms or contractures. Option D - Congenital scoliosi: Congenital scoliosis is a lateral curvature of the spine that is present at birth and is due to malformations of the vertebrae. It can cause asymmetry in the shoulders and hips but does not typically present with the specific elevated and medially rotated scapula described in the question Reference: ...

questions.question: A 30-year-old patient has limited hip movement and complains of pain and discomfort in the hip region . Which of the following test is done to identify flexion deformity at the hip?
questions.explanation: to measure hip extension. If the patient has a hip flexion contracture, the contralateral knee will rise off the examination table when the hip on the affected side is extended. Incorrect Options: Option C - Telescopy: Identifies hip instability by moving the patient's leg in circular motion, observing for abnormal hip joint movement, confirmed by visible and palpable greater trochanter displacement. Option B - Lasegue test: Identifies lumbar radiculopathy or sciatica by lifting the patient's straight leg while lying flat, pain indicating nerve root compression. Option D - McMurray test: Assesses knee meniscal tears by bending, twisting, and extending the patient's knee, pain or "click" suggests tear.
